name: Lumbini
fun_fact: Fun fact: Lumbini is the birthplace of Siddhartha Gautama (Buddha) in 563 BCE - the exact spot is marked by the Maya Devi Temple. Emperor Ashoka visited in 249 BCE and erected a pillar that still stands today, making it one of the oldest Buddhist pilgrimage sites in the world!

hero_dishes.name: Dal Bhat
hero_dishes.description: Rice with lentil soup, vegetable curries, and pickles - Nepal's national meal
hero_dishes.origin_story: The saying goes 'Dal Bhat power, 24 hour' - eaten twice daily, it's the fuel of Nepal
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Local restaurants, guesthouses, every Nepali home

hero_dishes.name: Tharu Cuisine
hero_dishes.description: Food of the indigenous Tharu people - ghonghi (snail curry), wild game, river fish
hero_dishes.origin_story: The Terai plains are Tharu homeland - their cuisine features local river fish and unique preparations

hero_dishes.name: Momos
hero_dishes.description: Tibetan-style dumplings filled with vegetables or buffalo meat, with spicy tomato achaar
hero_dishes.origin_story: Originally from Tibet, momos are now Nepal's most beloved snack

hero_dishes.name: Sel Roti
hero_dishes.description: Ring-shaped sweet rice bread, deep-fried and crispy
hero_dishes.origin_story: Traditional Nepali festival food - made for Tihar and Dashain celebrations
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Morning street vendors, festivals, tea shops

signature_drinks.name: Chiya (Nepali Tea)
signature_drinks.description: Sweet milk tea with spices - the social lubricant of Nepal
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Multiple times daily from tiny glass cups - every tea shop serves it

signature_drinks.name: Fresh Sugarcane Juice
signature_drinks.description: Pressed fresh from sugarcane on the Terai plains
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: From roadside vendors - refreshing in the subtropical heat

food_culture_notes: Food near monasteries is often vegetarian out of respect for Buddhist practices
The Terai region has different cuisine from Kathmandu - more rice, fish, tropical fruits
Simple pilgrim food dominates - many visitors are on religious journeys
International Buddhist monasteries sometimes serve food from their home countries
